sp.p: Wilte thou then ſaye that faith is not true faith, if ſhe be not declared by works which God requireth of vs in his lawe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is fayth,Iames. 1. • . as the fire that is without heat and light, is fire.

div.head: Of the good workes which God requireth of the faithfull.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Séeing the matter is ſo, tell mée then in bréefe what works god requireth of vs in his law, to teſtifie of our fayth, as well towards him, as towards men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Wée may comprehend them all ſummarily in two points.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The inuocation of the name of god.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſecōd?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The charitie towards our neybor.

div.head: Of the inuocation of the name of God.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: What things comprehendeſt thou vnder the inuocation of the name of God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do comprehende thrée, in taking it generally as I take it here.Pſal. 50. c. &. c Epheſ. 5. d Hebr. 13. c Rom. 10. d 1. Cori. 10. d

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſte?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ſupplication and prayer: whereby we haue recourſe to God in all our neceſſities.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſecond?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is thankeſgiuing, wherby we acknowledge the goodneſſe that wée haue receyued of him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The thirde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is the profeſſion and confeſſion of our faith and religiō, by the which he wil be aduowed and glorified in vs towards al men, as our God.

div.head: Of the ſum of the firſt table of the law.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: It ſemeth to me that theſe thre points conteyne as it were a ſūme of all the firſt Table of the lawe.Roma. 10. •

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
If we adde therevnto faith which is the true fountaine of all theſe things,1. Corin. 6. •
this ſummarie ſhalbe full and perfecte.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: For that that it ſhall comprehende the manner, how God will be ſerued and honored of vs, as well in harte as in word and in outward works.

div.head: Of the ſumme of the ſecond Table.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What doth the charitie towarde our neighboure comprehende?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We may in like ſorte bring it all into two pointes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which is the firſte?Exod. 20. Epheſ. 6. a. 1. Peter. 2. a 1. Cor. 13. b Leuit. 19. c. Matth. 7. b.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The honor and obedience whiche we owe to all thoſe that the Lorde hath appointed ſuperiors and gouernours ouer vs.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: The other?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The care whiche we ſhould haue both in generall and eſpeciall the one of the others, as of our ſelues.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What doſt thou vnderſtande by this care?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
That we oughte with all our power to procure the honoure and profite of all men, and to let their diſhonour and hurte, as wel in ſoule
as in body, and goodes, and name.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It ſeemeth to mée that thou haſte agayn here made a little Summarie of all the commaundementes comprehended in the ſecond table of the lawe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is euen ſo.

div.head: Of Prayer.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: Folowing on the ſame which we haue ſayde of Faithe, and of the workes and frutes of the ſame, I haue yet to demaūd thée one thing concernyng the inuocation of the name of God.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It is concerning prayer, and the manner howe to pray, which things we muſt vſe.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: We can not followe a more certaine rule in that reſpect that that which Ieſus Chriſte himſelfe hath giuen vs.Matth. 6. b Luke. 11. a.

div.head: The forme of Prayer giuen by Ieſus Chriſte.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the forme of Prayer?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Our father whiche arte in heauen: Thy name be halowed: Thy kingdom come: Thy will be done in earth as in heauen: Giue vs thys day our dayly bread: Pardon vs all our offences, euen as we forgiue
them that haue offended againſt vs: And leade vs not into temptation, but deliuer vs from the euill. For thyne is the kingdome, power and glorie for euer and ouer. Sobeit.

div.head: Diuiſion of the matters conteyned in the Lordes Prayer.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What doth this forme of prayer comprehende in ſumme?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We may diuide the whole in two partes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The preface of the ſame.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: And whiche is the ſeconde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The requeſtes therin made.

div.head: Of the addreſſe of the Chriſtians in their prayers, and of their true aduocate in the ſame.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What dothe he teache vs in that preface?Pſal. 50. c.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: To whome we ought to direct all oure Prayers, and by what mediator and aduocate.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To whom muſt wée make our prayers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To God only,Iohn. 14. b. 16. c. as to our very heauenly father, vnto whom onely that honoure is reſerued, and is due.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p:
And whome ſhall wée take for
aduocate and mediatoure towards him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Him only by whome he is made our father,Rom. 8. g. 1. Timo 2. b 1. Iohn. 2. a. and through whome we may call vppon him as vpon our father.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which is he?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ieſus Chriſte, his well beloued Sonne, by whome only we are made the children of God, where as naturally we were the children of wrath.

div.head: VVhat thinges vve ought to demande of God, in our prayers.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What ſaiſt thou touching the requeſt made in that forme of prayer?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That it is not lawfull for any man, to deſire or demaunde of God, any other thing than that which is conteyned in them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What is it that is comprehended in them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: All that which man may iuſtly deſire and demaunde, as well for the glory of God, as for his owne ſaluatiō & all his neceſſities.

div.head: A diuiſion of the requeſts conteyned in the Lorde his prayer.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Howe many requeſtes be there in the whole?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sixe.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p:
By what order are
they diſpoſed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The thrée firſte haue regarde chiefly to that which concerneth the glory of God.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: And the other thrée?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To that whiche is neceſſary for man, as well for this corporall life, as for his eternall ſaluation.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Wherefore did our Lord Ieſus Chriſt in this matter obſerue this order.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To teach vs,Matth. 7. d 1. Corin. 10. g how we ought to frame all oure deſires to the glory of God, and that we ought to haue the ſame in moſt ſpeciall recommendation, and to ſubmitte vnto the ſame all thoſe thinges which we require of him for vs.

div.head: Of the miniſterie of the Church, and of the vſe of the ſame.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Now ſeing that true faith, is the very foundation of our ſaluation, and the true fountaine of all good works, tel me nowe, how we may obtayne the ſame.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thou moughteſt already vnderſtande it, by that whiche we haue ſayde, of the viuification and ſanctification of the faithfull, by the holy Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
I vnderſtande wel that it is a gifte of God, whiche is giuen to vs by the holy Ghoſt, but God is the meane by
the whiche the holy Ghoſte is ſerued in this woorke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The miniſterye of the worde of God, whiche hée hathe ordeyned in his Churche to that ende.

div.head: Of the partes of the miniſterie of the Churche.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Mat. 18. b. c.What conteyneth this miniſterie?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We may make thrée parts of it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſt?1. Corin. 1. b.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The adminiſtration of the pure worde of God.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſecond?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The adminiſtration of the ſacramentes ordeyned in the ſame.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The thirde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The conſeruation of the diſcipline of the Churche.

div.head: Of the diſcipline of the Churche.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: What meaneſt thou by that diſcipline?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The pollicie which ought to be had in the Churche, to keepe all things in good order in the ſame, according to the worde of God.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To what ende ſerueth that policie?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is ſo neceſſary in the Church, that without the ſame, the admiſtration of the word & of the ſacraments, can not there be entertayned & conſerued in his right & authoritie, as is requiſite.

div.head: Of the Sacraments that are in Chriſtes Church, and of the things that ar to be conſidereed in them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What calleſt thou ſacramentes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ſignes taken of viſible thyngs: the whiche Ieſus Chryſte hath ioyned to his promiſes,Mat. 26. • 28. d. euen as it were to ſeale vnto vs the truth of them, and to confirme the ſame vnto vs.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What thinges are there to be conſidered in them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There are thrée things principall.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The worde of God,1. Cor. 11. c. Rom. 4. b. which is the very foundation.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſecond?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The viſible ſignes whiche are as ſeales.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The third?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The things ſignified as well by the worde as by the ſignes.

div.head: Of the things that are to be conſidered in the woorde.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What is there to be conſidered in the worde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Two things.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The cōmandement of God, by the whiche we are bounde to his holy Sacraments.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſecond?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is the promiſe by the which he doth aduertiſe vs of the grace that he doth offer and beſtow vpon vs in them.

div.head: Of the vſe of the ſignes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: To what purpoſe ſerue the ſignes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To repreſente to the eyes, and to the other corporall ſenſes, the things that are ſignified by the worde.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What profite commeth of this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It ſerueth for greater declaration of them, and for a more greater confirmation of the faith.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Do they ſerue to any other purpoſe than this.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As God by them on his parte declareth, his good affection toward vs, aduertiſing vs of the good that he will do to vs. We alſo of our parte, do ſet forth and declare our faith,1. Cor. 11. e. 1. Peter. 3. d. and our harte and affection towards him by them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: The ſacraments then by this accoumpte, are as witneſſes and ſolemne othes, by whome wede as it were homage to God, and do make profeſſion of our faith and Religion.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is euen ſo.

div.head: Of the number of Sacraments vvhich are in the Chucrhe of Chriſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How many Sacramentes are there in Chriſt his Church?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
There are but two whiche may be properly accoumpted for
true Sacraments.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which is the firſte?Matth. 28. d Matth 26. c 1. Cor. 11. e.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That of baptiſme.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: And the ſeconde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ſupper.

div.head: Of Baptiſme.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What is baptiſme?Tite. 3. b Epheſ. 5 e. f. Galath. • . d Rom. 6. a.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is a ſacramēt by the which Ieſus Chriſt doth offer vnto vs the remiſſion of our ſinnes, and our regeneration, vnder the figure of the water, as he doth in déede communicate the ſame vnto vs by his holy ſpirite.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Doth it any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In like ſorte it teſtifieth to vs that he receyueth vs into his Churche, as true members of the ſame.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: And of our parte, what do we?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We teſtifie in lyke ſorte, that we acknowledge him for ſuche an one as he declareth himſelfe towardes vs, and that we beleue that he maketh vs partakers of all his great riches.

div.head: Of the Supper.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What is the ſupper?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is a Sacrament by the which Ieſus Chriſt doth preſent vnto vs vnder the ſignes of bread and wine, the communion that we haue with him, and with his Church.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Is there nothing
elſe repreſented vnto vs in it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ſpirituall nouriture that we haue by faith in his fleſh and in his bloud, whiche haue ben giuen for vs.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: And as touching the reſt, do we not there make the ſame profeſſion of our faith that we do in baptiſme.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo vnderſtood, for ſo muche as ſuch is the nature of all Sacraments, and one of the principall ends and purpoſes for the which they are ordeyned of God.

div.head: To vvitte vvhether the bread & the wine be conuerted into the body and bloud of Ieſus Chriſt in the Supper.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Doſt thou thinke that this bread and this wine that are giuen for ſignes in the Sacramente, be the very naturall body and bloud of Ieſus Chriſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If they were his very naturall bodie and bloud, they could then not be the ſignes of it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: For ſo much as if it were ſo, there ſhould be no difference betwene the ſignes and the things whiche they ſignifie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Is there none other inconuenient?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
There is alſo this inconuenient, that if it were ſo this doctrine ſhoulde be wholly contrary to the articles of oure faith, and namely
to that of the aſcention of Ieſus Chriſt into heauen.

div.head: Of the coniunction of the ſignes in the ſupper, vvith the thinges that they ſignifie.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Doſt thou then thinke that the body and bloud are vnited and ioyned togither naturally and corporally, with the bread and the wine?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, eſpecially for two cauſes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſte?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seing there is queſtion of ſpirituall nouriture, in this holy Table, we may not imagine here a materiall meate, which is eaten on the ſame table, as is bodily meate.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Which is the ſecond?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is that we ſhal fall into the ſame inconuenient, whereof we haue euen now ſpoken, touching the articles of our faith.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Do we then receiue ther nothing els but material bread and wine?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes that we do.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The very body and bloud of Ieſus Chriſt, ſignified to vs by them.

div.head: Of the preſence of the body and bloud of Ieſus Chriſt in the Supper.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How may we receiue them, if they be not there, euen as thou ſaiſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I ſayd not but that they were in dede in the ſupper,
or otherwiſe it ſhould not be the true ſupper of Ieſus Chriſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How doſt thou thē vnderſtande it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Albeit that I denie the bodie and the bloud to be there naturally and carnally, I denie not therefore but that they be there giuen and receyued ſpiritually in déede, euen as that ſacramente witneſſeth it vnto vs.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thou doeſt not then denie the preſence of the very body and very bloud of Ieſus Chriſt in the ſupper?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What wilte thou then ſay for full reſolution?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will only ſay, that the manner of that preſence, is not carnall and materiall, but ſpirituall and diuine.

div.head: Of them to vvhome the communion of Sacramentes doth belong.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Seing then we vnderſtande what the true nature of Sacraments is, ſhewe me now which they be to whome they oughte to be adminiſtred.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is eaſie to vnderſtand by that which hath alredy bin ſaid of the nature of them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: How doſt thou vnderſtand it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Seing they be as ſeales of the worde of God, and of the alliance that he hath made with his people, and as
a proteſtation of our faith towarde the ſame, the matter is very playne,Rom. 4. b that they belōg but only to thoſe which vouch that doctrine and aliance, and are compriſed in the ſame.

div.head: Of the proofe that is required of euery man in the Supper.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Bycauſe that the ſupper is not adminiſtred but to ſuch as are alredy at ye age of diſcretion,1. Cor. 11. f. ſhew me how euery man ought to prepare himſelf for to receiue the ſame?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sainct Paule giueth the rule when he admoniſheth euery mā to proue himſelfe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: What meaneth he by that proofe of himſelfe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That euery man do diligently examine him ſelfe, whether he haue in him the things without the which he may not worthyly communicate at the holy Sacramente.

div.head: Of the principall points vppon the which euery man ought to examine and proue himſelfe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche be thoſe things?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There be chiefly thrée, as men maye iudge, by the matters that we haue handled heretofore.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſt?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: It is true repentaunce, and a true acknowledging of his offences and ſinnes, for the whiche Ieſus Chriſte dyed, as he declareth vnto vs by the ſame holy ſacrament.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Whiche is the ſecond?Marke. 1. b

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: True faith in the onely grace and mercie of God, whiche is offered and graunted vnto vs in Ieſus Chryſt, and by Ieſus Chryſt, as that Sacrament alſo teſtifyeth.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: The thirde?2. Cor. 10. d

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: True charitie and vnion towarde all the membres of Ieſus Chriſt, as it is repreſented vnto vs, in that wée there eate all of one ſelf bread, and drink all of one ſelfe cuppe.

div.head: Of the miniſters of the Churche, and of Magiſtrates.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: There reſteth nowe but one pointe, it is to witte, by whome theſe ſacramentes ought to be adminiſtred.Matth. 28. d 16. d

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By thoſe ſame miniſters, to whome the charge to adminiſter the worde of God, hath bene committed by lawfull order, as he hathe ordeyned in his Churche.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Is it lawfull then for none other?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
As GOD
hath ordeyned that there ſhould be in the common wealth certain Magiſtrates and officers, for the adminiſtration of ciuile and earthlye matters, to the ende there ſhoulde be no confuſion: euen ſo hathe he willed his Churche to haue hir miniſters choſen by lawfull vocation, as his officers for the adminiſtration of Eccleſiaſticall and ſpirituall matters,Ephe. 4. b. to the ende that euery thing bée there handled and gouerned by good order.

div.head: A FAMILIAR expoſition of the principall points of the Cathechiſme, and of the Chriſtian doctrine, made in forme of Dialogue.
Of the true ſeruice of God, and of good intents. The first Dialogue.
Of the chiefe felicitie of man, and of the ende for the vvhich he vvas created of God.

sp.speaker: MATHEVV.
sp.p: WHat is that whiche naturally men do moſt deſire in this world?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.p: To be happie.

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: What is it to be happie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to be exempte & deliuered from all euils, to liue in perpetuall reſt and ioy, and to enioy al good things.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And wherin conſiſteth the true and chiefeſt felicitie of man whereby he may be happie in ſuch ſorte as thou haſt declared?Gene. 16.19. b. Prouer. 19. a Eſay. 43. a. Ezeche. 36.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
It conſiſteth in that, wherefore GOD hath
chéefly created him to his image and likeneſſe, and hath put him into the worlde.Pſal. 115. • Roma. 11. d 1. Cor. 6. d. Colloſs. 1. c Deut. 4. b 6. a. 32. a Matth. 1. a Iohn. 17 a Ephe. 1. b. c

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is then the principal cauſe for the which he hath created and placed him in the worlde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to be glorified in him and by him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Whiche is the verie true meane whereby God maye bée glorified in mā, & by man?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By the true knowledge of him, which cauſeth man to honour him as his God and creator, with that honour whiche is due vnto him, and that he requireth of him.

div.head: Of the true honor and ſeruice of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is that honour which God requireth of man?1. Par. 15. a Miche. 6. b Deut. 10. c

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That he doe him homage, and ſubmit him wholly to him thorough true obedience towardes his holye will.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: By what meane maye a man knowe that will of God?

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: By the declaration that God him ſelfe hathe made by his word.

div.head: Of the ſumme of all the Doctrine conteyned in the holy ſcriptures.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Whiche be the principall poyntes to
conſider in that word reueled by God.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There be two, to the whiche a man maye applie in general, all ye doctrine that it cō teyneth & ſetteth forth to man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which be they?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The lawe, and the Goſpell.

div.head: Of the lawe of God, and of the office of the ſame.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Vnderſtandeſt thou by the law thoſe cōmandements only which God gaue to Moyſes in two tables of ſtone?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I do cō prehēd thē vnder this name of law:Exod. 32. d 34. a. 30. Luke. 24. c Deut. 5. Pſal. 19. c 2. Tim. 4. d Ro. 3. c. 4. c 5. d. 7. b 2. Cor. 3. b. c Galath. 3. •
but I do cōprehend in ye ſame alſo al the reſt of the doctrine of God, conteined in the holy ſcriptures: whereby he ſetteth forth to vs ye very ſame things that he cōmandeth vs in thoſe two tables.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Declare the ſame ſomwhat more plainly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I comprehend vnder the name of lawe, all the doctrine by the whiche God hath ſhewed vnto vs, the good which he alloweth & requireth of vs, as by right we are boūd thervnto: & in like ſort the euil which diſpleaſeth him, & from the whiche he willeth that we kepe our ſelues for his ſake, to ye end that in al things thorowly, wée yelde vnto him that perfect obediēce which we owe vnto him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hath ye law of God none other office?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It hath this office alſo, that by ye ſame mean it ſheweth vs our offēces & ſinnes, by the which we ſtande detters to the iudgement of God, and preacheth to vs forthwith the wrath and curſe of him that wée haue deſerued in offending of him.

div.head: Of the Goſpell, and of his office.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What vnderſtandeſt thou by the Goſpell?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I vnderſtand all the doctrine of the holy Scriptures, by the whiche God declareth vnto vs the grace that he will ſhewe vs by his ſonne Ieſus Chryſt, and the meanes whereby we are made partakers.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doeſt thou vnderſtande that doctrine to be conteyned in any other bookes of the holy Scriptures, than in thoſe of the foure Euangeliſtes?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: I vnderſtande that it is conteyned in all the holy Bible, and chiefly in the Bookes of the new Teſtament.

div.head: Of the difference that is to bee conſidered betwene the law and the Goſpell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What difference doeſt thou then put betwéene the lawe and the Goſpell?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I
take the law as a Proctor fiſcall, or a criminall iudge, which doth accuſe vs, and maketh our proces before God, in ſuche ſort as it yeldeth vs all condemned before the iudgement of God, as tranſgreſſours of all his commaundements: and by that meane, declareth vs all worthie of death and eternall damnation.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If it be ſo, the lawe ſerueth vs rather to condemnation, than to ſaluation.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is true, but it is not by the faulte of the law, but by our fault:Ro. 7. c. 8. a for the law of his nature is good, holy, and iuſt: but bicauſe that of our nature we are wicked, and doe not accompliſhe it at all, it dothe in ſteade of iuſtifying of vs, condemne vs.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And the Goſpell what newes bringeth it vnto vs?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Very good, and much better for vs than the law, as alſo his name declareth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: what then dothe Goſpell ſignifie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A meſſage of good,Rom. 3. d 5. c. d 2. Cor. 5. d. Galath. 3. d Heb. 12. c. f. happie, and ioyefull newes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hold me no longer in doubt, but tel them me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It ſheweth to vs the grace by the which we are diſcharged and ſette frée before the iudgement of God, and deliuered from that death and eternall damnation, to the which we are iuſtly condemned by
the lawe, and it declareth vnto vs by and by the meanes whereby wée obtaine that grace, and of whom.

div.head: Of the couenant and agreement of the lawe and the Goſpell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Séeing that the lawe (as thou ſayeſt) is to vs a meſſenger of death and damnation, wherto doth it then ſerue vs, but only to condemne vs?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It ſerueth vs in ſuch ſort to condemne vs, that if it did not condemne vs in this poynte, the Goſpell coulde not bring vs ſo greate wealth as it doth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How doſt thou vnderſtand this?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If we vnderſtande not of oure diſeaſe, we wil not repaire to the phiſition, which onely may deliuer vs, for we woulde not thinke that we had any neede. Likewyſe, if we ſhould not knowe our condemnation, we ſhoulde thinke we had no néede of grace,Gala. 3. d Hebr. 7. c. 3. b Math. 17. a g. b. Marke. 9. b. 2. c Luk. 9. c. 5. f & therfore we ſhould not demaund it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wilt thou then ſay, that the law is as it wer a phiſition, which ſheweth vs plainly our diſeaſe, and how dangerous it is, but he can not heale vs, but ſendeth vs to an other?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is euen ſo: And for that
cauſe Sainct Paule ſaith,Act. 3. d Heb. 12. g. 2. Timo. 6. c 1. c. Apo. 19. c. 1. Peter. 2. d that the lawe is giuen vs as a ſchoolemaſter of little children, to directe vs to the Goſpell, and by the ſame meane to Ieſus Chriſt, which is the chiefe and great maſter, which is alſo ſet forth to vs in the Goſpell, as the chiefe Phiſition. For there is but he only that can heale vs of that deadly diſeaſe, to wit, to deliuer vs from that eternall deathe, which the lawe ſheweth vs.

div.head: Of the cauſe for the vvhich God vvoulde him ſelfe declare his vvill vnto man by his vvorde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I vnderſtād now wel, that God would himſelfe declare his will vnto man by his owne worde, whiche comprehendeth all the doctrine of the law and of the Goſpel, but for what cauſe hath he done it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bycauſe he will not be ſerued according to the fantaſies of men, but according to hys owne only will.Deute. 12. a ••• . 10. c.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is the cauſe of this?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is bycauſe that there is but his will only that is iuſt and reaſonable, and that oughte to be a rule of all reaſon and iuſtice vnto mē. For the which cauſe,
he hath generally forbidden all men,Col. 2. b. d. Deuter. 4. a 12. d. Pro. 30. a. of what eſtate or condition ſoeuer they be, to adde or diminiſh any thing to or fro his lawe and worde, which he hath reuealed as well by his Prophets and Apoſtles, as by his owne ſonne Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: Of the good intentes of men that are not gouerned by the vvord of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How thinkeſt thou then of thoſe which ſaye, that whatſoeuer is done to the honoure of God, and with a good intente, is well done?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I denie not but that whiche is done to the honoure of God, doth pleaſe him, and that whiche is done with a good intent, is well done: but to the ende that no man deceiue himſelfe vnder this faire coloure, I ſay, that nothing can be done to the honoure of God nor with a good intente, but that which is done according to his word, for the word of God is the very true and only rule of all good intents, and of the honoure wherewith he ought to be honoured.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But if a man do think to do well, and doth that whiche he doth to none other ende but to honoure God, is not that inough?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
If there were but that required, it had not ben nedeful that God
ſhould euer haue ſpoken: or that he ſhuld euer haue giuen a law vnto man, to teach him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wherfore ſayſt thou ſo?

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: For that that it had then ben ſufficient to haue let euery man liue according to his fantaſie, and that he had only commaūded, that euery man ſhoulde doe that whiche liked him, without giuing them any other law, where he hath doone cleane contrary,Deuter. 4. a &. 12. a ſaying: Do not euery one of you that which ſhall pleaſe you, but that onely whiche I commaunde you.

div.head: Of humaine traditions.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What thynkeſt thou then of lawes and of mens traditions, which haue bene ſet foorth by men,Eſay 29. d Matth. 15. a Marke. 7. a contrary to the woord of God, touching his ſeruice?

sp.speaker: P
sp.p: I will ſaye nothing to thee of my ſelfe, but onely that which god himſelf hath ſaid by the mouth of his prophete Eſay, and that whiche he hath yet afterwarde more confirmed by that of his ſonne Ieſus Chriſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What hath he ſayde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That hee is ſerued in vayne by the doctrines and commaundements of men.

div.head: Of the ſeruice of God according to the traditions of men.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: DOeſt thou thinke by that, that they which ſerue him in that ſort do loſe wholly their tyme, and that hée dothe not accept it at their hands?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: They doe not only loſe their tyme,1. Sam. 15 • Matth. 6. d Hebr. 11. d Rom. 14. a but they doe alſo greatly diſhonor God, and do prouoke his wrath vpon them.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For ſo muche as whatſoeuer is doone withoute faith cannot pleaſe him, but is ſinne, whiche greatly diſpleaſeth him.

div.head: Of the difference of the true and falſe fayth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: BVt if they which ſerue God according as they haue ben taught of mē doe the ſame faithfully, may they then do it without faithe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It fareth with thys good faith, wherof thou nowe ſpeakeſt,Iohn. 6. g. 17 b Rom. 10. d Tit. 1. a. Hebr. 11. a as it doth with good intents, wherof we euen now ſpake.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How vnderſtandeſt thou that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
As ther ar no good intēts, but thoſe whiche are gouerned by the only rule of the wil and word of God, euen ſo is there no true faith, but that which hath certain
and ſure foundation in the ſame worde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shew me the ſame ſomething more plainly.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When thou doeſt any thing at aduenture, canſt thou doe it with certaine aſſurance?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I confeſſe that I doe it in dout.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou mayſt then vnderſtād therby, that thou doeſt it not in fayth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bicauſe that faith & doubt are as contrarie as is to be certayne and vncertayn.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Howe maye that bée?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bicauſe that faith is neuer without true aſſurance of that whiche it beléeueth and followeth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why may it not be without ſuche aſſurance?Ro. 1. d. 8. g. Eph. 3. c. a. c. Philip. 2. a Hebr. 11. a. b. Iam. 1. a.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bicauſe that ſhée is buylded vpon the ſure word of God, by the whiche ſhe is aſſured of his good will.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What followeth thereof?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That ſhe doth nothing at aduenture, but is euer certaine, that that whiche ſhe beléeueth, and that which ſhe doth, is pleaſant to God.

div.head: Of the aſſurāce of the cōſcience by the word of God, and what cōmoditie commeth therby to man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat commoditie doth this aſſurance bring to mā?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The greteſt yt he could deſire.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shew me what it is.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is not only one, but two, which
are very great.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is yt man ſheweth by the ſame the reurence that he beareth to the maieſtie of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wherin?Deut. 6. a. 10. •

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In that yt he feareth not only to offend him, in yt which he plainly knoweth to diſpleaſe him, but alſo in yt wherof he is yet in dout.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What reuerence of God is there in this laſt point?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is this, yt man hath the maieſtie of God in ſuch eſtimation, & beareth him ſo great reuerēce, yt not only he wil not wittingly offend him, but alſo he will not put himſelf in any hazard, nor do any thing at aduenture, whēther is queſtiō of ye honor & ſeruice of god.Rom. 5. a. 8. • Ephe. 2. d. Galla. 4. a. Heb. 4. d. And therfore he wil euer be aſſured of his will.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Whiche is the other point?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The quietneſſe of a good cō ſcience that man hath by that mean, when he is aſſured that he pleaſeth God, by an aſſurance ſo certaine, founded vppon the witneſſe of God himſelfe.

div.head: Of the Lawe of God. The ſecond Dialogue.
Of the manifeſtation of the wil of God by the law of the two Tables.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: SEing then that wée muſte in euery reſpect gouern our ſelues according to the rule of Gods worde,Exod. 20. a 32. d. 34. a. d Deute. 5. a. b & 9. b. folowing the reſolution whiche wée haue euen nowe made, ſhewe me now firſt of all, what is that he commaundeth vs in his lawe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He himſelfe hath made vs a bréefe gathering or collection of the principall pointes that the doctrine therof comprehendeth in his commaundements that he hath giuen to his people, by the hands of Moyſes his ſeruaunt, written in thoſe two tables of ſtone, wherof thou haſte euen nowe made mention.

div.head: Of the number of the commaundementes conteyned in the two tables.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: HOwe manye commaundementes dothe the firſte Table conteyn?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Foure with the Preface, which the Lord vſed at the beginning.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And the ſecōde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sixe, which being ioyned to the firſte foure, make ten in the whole.

div.head: The firſt table of the lawe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHich is that preface whereof thou haſt made mention?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Herken Iſrael: It is I that am the Eternal thy God, who hath drawn thée out of the land of Egypte, from the houſe of bondage.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt commandement?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt haue no ſtraunge Gods before me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The ſecond?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt make no image nor likeneſſe of the things that be there aboue in heauen, nor here belowe in the earth, nor in the waters vnder the earth.

Thou ſhalt do them no reuerence, neither ſhalt thou ſerue them: for I my ſelf, I am the Eternall thy God, mightie and iealous, who doe venge my ſelfe of the iniquitie of the fathers vppon their children, and vpon the children of their children, yea euen to the thirde and fourthe line of thoſe that hate me, and do ſhewe fauour in a thouſand generatiōs to them that loue me and kéepe my commaundementes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The third?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not take in vaine the name of the Eternall thy God. For the Eternall will not hold him for innocent that ſhall take his name in vayne.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: The fourthe?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Remember
thée to ſanctifie the daye of reſt. Sixe dayes thou ſhalte laboure and ſhalte doe all thy buſineſſe: but the ſeauenth daye is the reſt of the eternall thy God. Thou ſhalte in the ſame doe no kinde of workes, neyther thou, nor thy Sonne, nor thy daughter, neyther thy man ſeruaunt nor thy woman ſeruaunt, neyther thy cattell, neyther the ſtraunger which abydeth with thée.

For in ſixe dayes the Eternall made the Heauen, the Earth and the Sea, and all that which is in them, & did reſt in the ſeauenth daye. And therefore the Eternall did bleſſe the daye of reſt, and ſanctified it.

div.head: The ſeconde Table.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: REcite them of the ſeconde table, and ſhewe me whiche is the fyrſte thereof.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The firſt of that table, is the firſt folowing the order of the foure going before.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is it? Honoure thy father and thy mother, to the end that thy dayes may be long vppon the earth, that the Eternall thy GOD gyueth thée.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The ſixte.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalte not kyll.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The ſeauenth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not be a fornicatour or adulterer.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The eighte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not ſteale.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The ninth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalte not beare falſe witneſſe agaynſt thy neyghboure.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The tenth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not couet thy neyghbours houſe, nor his wife, nor his man ſeruant, nor his woman ſeruant, nor his Ox • , nor his aſſe, nor any thing that is his.

div.head: Of the ſum of the lavve.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat doe the commaundements of theſe two tables conteyne in ſubſtance?Matth. 22. d Mark. 12. a. Luke. 10. c

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ieſus Chryſte hath gyuen vs the ſum, reducing into two poyntes, all the doctrine compriſed in them.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the ſum?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Hearken Iſraell: the Eternall thy God is God only. Thou ſhalte loue the Eternall thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy ſoule: and with all thy vnderſtanding. It is the firſt and the greate commaundement.Leuie. 19. d. And the ſecond like to the ſame is. Thou ſhalt
loue thy neyghbour as thy ſelfe:Matth. 7. d. All the lawe and the Prophets depende of theſe two commaundements: All things then that you would that men did to you, doe you the ſame vnto them, for it is the law and the Prophetes.

div.head: Of the diuiſion of the matters ſet foorth in the lawe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat doe theſe two poynts comprehende in effecte?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: The firſt comprehendeth all the commaundementes of the firſt table.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: What do theſe commaundementes of the firſte table comprehende in ſubſtance?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: All that whiche God requireth of man, eſpecially touching his owne perſon and maieſtie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And the ſecond poynt of the ſayd ſūme what conteyneth it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: All the commaū dementes of the ſecond table.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it that God requireth of man in them?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That whiche he woulde that all men ſhuld do one to an other, for ye loue of him.

div.head: The diuiſion of the poyntes conteined in the firſte table: and of the principall parts of the true ſeruice of god.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHiche be the principall pointes that he requireth of man, eſpecially concerning the perſon and maieſtie of God?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A man may in mine opinion, reduce them all chiefly in two generally.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The faith toward him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And the ſeconde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The teſtifying and manifeſting of the ſame.

div.head: Of the faith tovvards God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat requireth he in the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That man holde him for the only and true God, ſetting all his harte and all the truſt of his ſaluation in him only, and in no other thing whatſoeuer.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Is faith then the chiefe and principall foundation of the honoure and ſeruice whiche man oweth to God?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It cannot otherwiſe be.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For that yt euē as it is impoſſible to pleaſe God without faith, euen ſo all that which is done without faith, maye be but ſinne, as we haue heretofore ſaide.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is the cauſe thereof?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is bicauſe that faith is the true fountaine of that true and perfecte obedience whiche God requireth of man
towarde his holy will.Deut. 6. d. 10. c. d. 32. f. Wherefore he requireth it foorthwith in the firſt commandement of his lawe, with the whole harte of man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shew me this ſomewhat more familiarly.Eſay. 43. b.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will ſay in effecte, that God requireth that man do ſo ſet all his harte and al his truſt in his God, that, he attende from him only, all goodneſſe, and of none other whatſoeuer,Hebr. 11. a Rom. 14. b. and that in all thinges he depende of none other but of him only.

div.head: Of the teſtifying and declaring of faith, and of the partes thereof.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat meaneſt thou by the teſtifying and ſhewing foorth of faith,Matth. 7. c. Galath. 5. a. Hebr. 11. Iames. 2. c. d. whiche thou haſt placed for the other point?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: The teſtimonie whereby man giueth to vnderſtande by the frutes that his faith bringeth forth in him, that it is not vaine, fained nor dead, but that it is true, liuely and ſounde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which be the frutes that yeld ſuch teſtimonie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: We may bring them all into thrée points.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The calling vppon the name of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The ſeconde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thanſgiuing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The thirde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The charitie towards our neyghboure: but this apperteyneth more aptly to the ſeconde table of the lawe.

div.head: Of the inuocation of Gods name, and of the true vvorshipping of him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat meaneſt thou by the inuocation of gods name?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I meane a pure affectiō of harte, whereby faith maketh a man to run only to God in all his neceſſities,Pſal. 50. e. 14 4. d. Iohn. 4. c. Deuter. 4. c. Matth. 5.6. a. Eſay. 1. d. and to worſhip him in ſpirite and truth as he requireth in the ſecōd and third commaundement.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it to worſhip God in ſpirite and truth?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to honoure God with a true affection, procéeding from a pure and cleane harte, and not by Images and other viſible and corruptible thinges, or elſe by ſhewes and outwarde ceremonies.

div.head: Of thankſgiuing.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat meaneſt thou by thankſgiuing, which thou haſt ſet forthe for the ſecond point?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I meane that euen as God will haue man to call vppon
his name,Pſal. 50. c. 116. b. Hebr. 13. c he will alſo that he acknowledge the benefits yt he hath receiued of him, and that he yelde him thanks in ſuch ſorte as he himſelfe hath ordeyned, for the glory of his name, which is alſo a point that he requireth in the thirde and fourth commaundemente.

div.head: Of the outvvard teſtimonie of faith, vvhich God requireth of man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: SEing that God wil be ſerued in ſpirite and truth, as thou haſt ſaide, is not he contented, that euen as man in his heart beléeueth in him, that euen ſo in his heart he call vppon his name, and yelde him thanks?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That ſhould be ſufficiente as towards God.Pſalm. 7. e. Iere. 17. b. Act. 1. d. Apoca. 2. f. For ſo much as he knoweth well what is in the heart of man, withoute any néede of other teſtimonie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wherefore is it then that he yet requireth, that man yelde outwarde teſtimonie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He doth it chiefly for two cauſes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to that ende that man deceiue not himſelfe, making himſelfe to beléeue that he hath true faith in God, when he hath none at all.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How may he know whether he haue faith or no,Mat. 7. d. 13. d 25. a. Iames. 1. d. 2. c. d. Mat. 7. c Iames. 2. c. d. by that meane whiche thou ſpeakeſt of?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euē as the trée is knowne by his frutes, and the workeman by hys worke, and the cauſe by his effecte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſeemeth to me that whiche thou ſaiſt, is a better meane to cauſe others to knowe whether he haue faith or no,Rom. 2. b. 2. Peter. 1. b. Math. 5. b. Iohn. 15. b. Rom. 10. b. 1. Peter. 2. b. then hymſelfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If others maye knowe it by this meane, there is no doubte but ſuch a teſtimonie whiche he yeldeth to others, may well ſerue him for a proofe, and greater confirmation of his faith, when he ſhall ſée theſe frutes himſelfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the other reaſon that thou haſt alſo to thys purpoſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to the ende that God be glorified alſo before men, by the confeſſion and teſtimonie of the faith that is in the heart of the beléeuing man.

div.head: Of the meanes ordeyned to man by God, vvhereby they may make profeſsion of their faith.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat meanes hath he ordeyned to make confeſſion,Math. 18. c. 28. d. Exod. 10. b. 31. d. and to yelde teſtimonie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
The chiefe are the aſſemblies
of the faithfull, in the whiche he doth precide by his holy ſpirite, and by the miniſterie of his worde, for whoſe cauſes he hath chiefly ordeyned the daye of reſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What means are there in ſuch aſemblies,Deuter. 5. b. c. to make there this confeſſion?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There are thrée chiefly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The allowing and confeſſion of Lordes doctrine, whiche is there ſet foorth by the preaching of the Goſpell.1. Corin. 14. c.

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: Whiche is the ſecond?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The publique and common prayers of the Churche.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the thirde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is the communion of the Sacramēts adminiſtred by the ordinance of God in thoſe aſſemblies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I would willingly learne of thée whiche be theſe Sacramentes?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It were better that we deferred this matter to an other time, to the ende that we continued the purpoſe which we haue in hand at this preſente, touching the matters compriſed in theſe commandementes of the lawe of God.

div.head: Of the charitie tovvards our neyghboure.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
WE haue alredy handled two points touching the frutes of faith, tell me
now which is the thirde and laſt?Leuit. 19. d. Iohn. 13. d. Rom. 13. b.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is the charitie that God requireth of euery man one to another.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Seing that faith hath his proper regarde to God only and to the commandements of the firſt table, and charitie hath his regarde to our neyboure and to the commaundementes of the ſecond table, as thou haſt ſaide heretofore. Tell me nowe what agréements there is betwene faith and charitie.Math. 5. g. 1. Iohn. 3. d. 4. c. d. 5. a.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Seing that faith hath regarde to God, he can not be without perfecte loue of him, neyther the perfect loue towards him maye be, but forthwith it extendeth to all hys children, and to all thoſe that he recommendeth vnto vs.

div.head: A diuiſion of the matters conteyned in the ſecond table.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat doth this charitie towards our neyghboure comprehende?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: All the commaundements of the ſecond table of ye law.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which be ye principal points of this charitie whereof thou ſpeakeſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: We maye likewiſe bring them all into two.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What doth GOD require in the firſte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
The honoure and the obedience that he willeth all inferiors
to yelde to their ſuperiors, whom he hath giuen vnto them for leaders and gouernors, in what eſtate ſoeuer they be, euen as the fifth commaundement of the lawe doth conteyne.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What requireth he in the ſeconde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The dutie wherevnto he hath egally and generally bounde al men one to another, and the honeſtie and iuſtice that all men oughte to kepe in theyr conuerſation in this world towards their God.1. Theſsa. 5. d. 1. Corin. 9. b.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What vnderſtādeſt thou by that iuſtice and honeſtie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That man kepe himſelfe pure and ſounde, as well in hys ſoule as in his body, to the ende he be not defiled, either by any violence or wrong that he ſhall do to his neyghboure, in any thing that may be, nor by any whoredome or filthineſſe whatſoeuer.

div.head: Of the points vvherein euery one is bounde to his neyghbour.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Matth. 22. d 1. Cor. 10. c. 13. b. Philip. 2. a Rom. 13. c. 12 c. d.DEclare to me more exactly what our dutie towards our neyghboure importeth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That we haue the ſame care for all men in generall that we haue for our ſelues.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
But wherein ought we to
haue this care for others?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There are two pointes to be conſidered herein.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That we take héede that we do them no diſhonour nor hurte, in any wiſe, be it in the ſoule, body, goods, or name.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the other?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That we procure their health, honoure and profite with all our power, in all thinges as the other fiue commaundemēts folowing do declare.

div.head: Of the vveakneſſe & defaulte of povver that is in man to accomplishe the lavve of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: AL that is very iuſt and very reaſonable, but is it in the power of mā, to yelde to God ſo ſounde and perfect obedience as he requireth of him?Gene. 6. b 8. d. Iere. 7. b. Rom. 8. b. 1. Cori. 2. d Gala. 5. c. d.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He hath not only not that power, but contrarily, it is fully impoſſible for him, to yelde vnto God ſuch an obedience. For according to his nature, he hath no pleaſure but to reſiſte againſt his holy will.

div.head: Of the fall and reſtoring of Man. The third Dialogue.
Rom. 6. d. 7. c. Epheſ. 2. a. 4. c. Galath. 5. c. Iohn. 3. d.Of mans Freevvill.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: HAth man no frée will, where by he maye doe the good that God commaundeth him, and refuſe the euill which he forbyddeth him?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He hath frée will without any power to do good: But on the contrarie, ſo prompt to all euill, that he deſireth not, (neyther can he) any other thing but to do euill, for the tyme that he remayneth in his corrupt nature.

div.head: Of ſinne, and of the nature of it, and what originall ſinne is properly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Geneſis. 3. Rom. 5. b. 7. c. Iohn. 8. d. Rom. 6. c. 2. Pet. 2. d. Epheſ. 2. a.WHat is the cauſe of this vnhappineſſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sinne wherevnto he became ſubiect thorowe his owne faulte, in ſuch ſorte, that he is as a ſeruaunt and ſlaue to ſinne.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How is ſinne the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Bycauſe that it bringeth to him two euilles, the greateſte that maye be.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pſal. 51. b. Epheſ. 2. a.Whiche is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is the wrath and curſe of God, whereof ſinne maketh
man guiltie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Whiche is the ſeconde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that corruption of nature whereof I haue already ſpoken, whiche maketh man ſo enclined to euill, that he cannot of himſelfe thinke, ſpeake, nor doe anye good, but procure dayly more and more the wrath of God vppon him, by all that whiche he can thinke, ſpeake, or doe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That corruption of nature, ought it to be accompted for ſin?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is properly that which is commonly called original ſinne, whiche is the ſpring and fountaine from whence all the others do procéede. Wherfore if there be any ſinne that deſerueth to be accompted ſinne, it is that ſame.

div.head: Of the meane vvhereby man maye be deliuered from ſinne, and from the vvrathe of God, vvhiche ſinne bringeth to him.

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: SEing then that mā can find in himſelfe no remedie to with-holde him from that bottomleſſe pitte of perdition,Iohn. 1. a. Rom. 5.7. d 8. a. Epheſ. 2. b. 4. f. where is it that he ſhal fynd it elſewhere?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
In God only, who only canne reforme hym to his Image, as at the fyrſte hee
did,Col. 2. c. 3. b 2. Timo. 1 c Tito. 3. b. Exod 20. e. Deuter. 5. a Hebr. 12.5. 1. Timo. 6. d and formed him according to ye ſame.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: But by what meane may he obtayne ſo greate a good thing of God, conſidering that he hath ſo greatly offended him, and procured his wrath?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is certaine, that no man may haue acceſſe to God, to obteyne ſaluation of him, without a mediatoure, by whome he may be made at one with him.

div.head: Of the cauſes for the vvhich there is neyther man nor Angell ſufficiente to the office of mediatoure betvvene God and man, and of the greatneſſe of the vvrath of God againſt ſinne.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Rom. 3. c. 5. b.ANd who is this mediatoure, which may make this appointmente?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For ſo much as all men, are in like faulte and condemnation, there is none among them ſufficient for that office, of what holyneſſe and qualitie ſoeuer he be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Where muſt he then be ſought? Shall it be among the Angells whiche haue no ſinne?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The very Angells can not be ſufficiente therevnto.Iob. 4. d. Colloſs. 1. b Epheſ. 1. b. Deuter. 4. d Nahum. 1. d Exod. 33. d. 34. a Pſal. 145. a. Iob. 46. d. 1. King. 8. c Daniel. 6. g. 13. b. Iſaye. 40. c. Pſal. 146. c. 1. Ti. 6. c. d. 2. Peter. 2. a Iude. • . Roma. 5. d. 1. Cor. 13. f Hebr. 2. d. Exod. 34. a. Rom. 3. e. d

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Chiefly for two cauſes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Whiche is the
firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that the wrath and curſſe of God, is ſo heauie a burden, that there is no creature whatſoeuer he be, neyther in heauen nor in the earth, that may beare it, but that he ſhall be beaten downe with it vtterly.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is the cauſe there?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is bicauſe that ye offence through ſinne committed, is done againſt God which is infinite, and an eternall prince and king, wherefore it deſerueth alſo paines infinite and eternall.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Haue we any teſtimonie of the ſame?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The angells which haue ſinned may be ſure teſtimonies vnto vs.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In what ſorte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If that they which were ſo excellent creatures, coulde not themſelues beare that which they had deſerued for their parte, how may one amongſt them beare all that that all mankind hath deſerued togither?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This reaſon is very plaine. But which is the other cauſe, that maketh that the very Angells are not ſufficient to ſuch an office?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For ſo much as ſeing that the offence was cō mitted by mā, it muſt alſo be repaired in him, & by him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For what cauſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To the ende that God may be founde true and iuſt, and alſo mercifull togither.

div.head: Of the ſetting forth of the iuſt iudgemēt, & of the mercy of god, in the redēptiō of mā.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Gene. 2. c. 3. c. d. Exod. 20. a. 34. a. Ezech. 18. e Iere. 3. d. Pſal. 103. b.HOw doſte thou vnderſtande ye ſame?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If god did not puniſh mā acording to the deſert of his tranſgreſſion, and according to the threatnings that he himſelf hath giuen vnto him, & the ſentence that he hath giuen againſt him, where ſhould the truth & iuſtice of God be?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I vnderſtand well this point, but what wilt thou ſay of his mercy?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In like ſort if he puniſhed man according to his deſert, where ſhould then this mercy be, by the which he ſheweth forth his infinit goodneſſe more than by any other vertue, whatſoeuer that is in him?

div.head: Of the only & true mediator Ieſus Chriſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Iohn. 3. b. Rom. 8. f. g. Rom. 5. b. 1. Iohn. 4. b. Eſay. 9. b. Iere. 23. b. Pſal. 45. b. Iohn. 1. a. b. 1. Tim. 3. d. Roma. 9. b. 1. Iohn. 1. a.If there be neyther man nor Angel ſufficient to that office, what other mean reſteth then, by the which that fault of man may be repaired by him, & in him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bycauſe that man could not among all the creatures find any, God hath prouided according to the pietie & compaſſion that he had of him, being moued by his only mercy and ineſtimable charitie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is this mean?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is yt he hath giuen his only ſonne Ieſus Chriſte to do this office.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And what mean hath he obſerued in this worke?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is that Ieſus
Chriſt being the Eternal & true God,Math. 1. e. d. Luke. 1. d. Act 3. c. 2. d Eſay. 53. b. c 1. Peter. 2. d & of one only eſſence with the father, toke humain fleſh in the womb of ye virgin Marie, by the very ordināce of God his father.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What néed was there that he ſhould take humain fleſhe vpon him to execute that office?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It was euen ſo neceſſarie to the ende that in the ſame, he might ſatiſfie the iuſt iudgement of God for all men.

div.head: Of the vnion of the diuine and humaine nature in the perſon of Ieſus Chryſt, and of the cauſes of the ſame.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Was it neceſſary that ye ſame mediator ſhould be very God and very man togither, in one very perſon?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is euen ſo, & chiefly for thrée cauſes.Rom. 5. d. Hebr. 2. d.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is, that if he had not bene very man, he could not haue ſuffred in our fleſh & nature yt which he hath ſuffered, & was to ſuffer for vs.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And if he had not ſuffred ye ſame, what incōuenience ſhuld ther haue ben?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
That he ſhuld not haue born for vs in our nature & fleſhe the wrath & curſe of God which we had deſerued: and then he ſhould not haue ſatiſfied the iudgement of God thorowe his obedience, to put away by the ſame, in our own fleſh and nature,
the rebellion by the whiche we haue deſerued this iudgemente.Nahum. b. Hebr. 10. g.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the other cauſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that if he had ben but only man, and that he had not ben vnited with God, being very God and very man in one very perſon, he could not haue ben able to beare this burden of the wrath of god, which is ſo greate and ſo importable, but that he ſhoulde haue ben ſwallowed vp, how iuſt or innocent ſoeuer he ſhulde haue ben.Eſay. 43. b. Iere. 17. a. Iohn. 6. g.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the thirde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that he ſhoulde not haue ben able alſo to haue brought ſaluation and life to man, if he had not had the fountaine in him ſelfe by meane of his diuine nature.

div.head: Of the ſacrifice and ſatiſfaction of Ieſus Chriſt, and of the vertue therof.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHich is then the meane whereby Ieſus Chriſte hath ſatiſfied for vs in his humaine nature and fleſhe?Eſay. 53. a. b Math. 27. Rom. 4. d. 5. a. 8. a. 2. Cor. 5. d. Epheſ. 5. a. 1. Pet. 2. c. d 1. Iohn. 2. a. Hebr. • . c. d

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is the ſacrifice that he himſelfe hath made of his owne body and bloud by his paſſion and death.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Howe is the ſacrifice of Ieſus Chriſt of ſuch vertue?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For two principall cauſes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Whiche is the
firſt?Phili. • . • Hebr. 5. • . 9. d.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The paine the which he béeing innocent hath endured for vs, whiche were culpable, by the which payne, he who had not deſerued it, hath deliuered vs from it which we haue deſerued.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the ſeconde?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is the perfecte obedience whiche he hath yelded to God his father, in recompence of the tranſgreſſion and rebellion which was founde in vs.

div.head: Of the communication in the benefites of Ieſus Chriſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: IS it ſufficiente that he is deade, and that he hath yelded to God his father one ſuch an obedience?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If that ſame were ynough, all ſhoulde be ſaued indifferently, as well infidels as faithfull men.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is more required then?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That the ſame ſatiſfaction whiche Ieſus Chriſte hath made to God his father, may be communicated and appiled to vs.

div.head: THE FOVRTH dialogue, is of the iuſtification and ſanctification of man.
Of the faith in Ieſus Chriſt, and of the Iuſtification thereby.

sp.speaker: MATHEVV.
sp.p: WHyche is the meane whereby to comme to that Communycation, wherof thou haſt euen nowe ſpoken, and by the whiche wée muſte communicate with Ieſus Chriſt?Act. 13. f. 15. b. Rom. 1. d. 3. d. Galath. 3. d. Rom. 6. a. 8. a. b 2. Cor. 1. b. 2. Cor. 5. d. Galath. 3. d. Epheſ. 5. g. 1. Peter. 1. a 1. Iohn. 1. b. c.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: There is none other but the only faith in Ieſus Chriſt: For by the ſame we are iuſtified before God, and not by our workes neyther in all, nor in parte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it to be iuſtified before God?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to be accoumpted for iuſt, at his iudgemente, as if we had neuer ſinned.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How maye this be done by the mean of faith?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Bycauſe that the ſpirite of God, by whome it is giuen vs, doth ioyne vs with Chriſt, as members of his body, by the meanes
of the ſame faith, in ſuch ſorte that the iuſtice of Chriſte and all that euer he hath done for vs, is imputed and aſcribed to vs as though it were our owne proper.

div.head: Of the iuſtificatiō by faith & by vvorks.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHy is this honoure rather giuen to faith than to works?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bycauſe there is no iuſtice that may ſatiſfie the iudgement of God, vnleſſe it be perfecte as is that of Ieſus Chriſte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why may not that of Ieſus Chriſt be as well allowed vnto vs by our works, as by faith?Rom. 3. d. e. 4. a. b. c. Galath. 3. Galath. 2. d.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bycauſe that they are things altogither cōtrary, to be iuſtified by faith & to be iuſtified by a mans owne works.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What contrarietie is there in that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If that man could find iuſtice in himſelfe and in his owne workes, whereby he mighte ſatiſfie vnto God, he ſhould then haue no neede of that of Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: Of the ſatiſfactiō tovvards god by works.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ANd if he may not ſatiſfie in euery pointe maye he not yet at the leaſt ſatiſfie in parte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If he cannot ſatiſfie him in the whole, no more can he in parte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For what cauſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Chiefly for two cauſes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Whiche is the firſte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that God receyueth no iuſtice for ſatiſfaction, if it be not ſound and perfect, and worthie of his maieſtie: as wee haue alreadie touched.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the other?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that man being naught and vniuſt of his nature, can doe no worke that may be iuſt (as we haue alſo ſayd) if he be not firſt made good and iuſt.

div.head: Of the works wherby man may ſatisfie at the iudgement of God.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: DOeſt thou meane by this, that the good and iuſte worke maketh not the man good and iuſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I doe not altogether denie,Pſalme. 14. a. b. Tit. 3. b. Tit. 2. d. 1. Tim. 2. b but that the good & iuſt work maketh the man good and iuſt: but I ſay, that mans worke can not doe this, bycauſe there procéedeth none ſuche from him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is then the work that may doe this?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That of Ieſus Chriſt, wherof wée haue ſpoken heretofore: whiche bringeth vnto vs this commoditie, when wée are made partakers of hym by the meane of Faythe, as wée haue alreadie ſayd.

div.head: Of the cauſes why iuſtification is attributed to faith only.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: SHEwe me nowe for full reſolution, what is the chiefe cauſe why iuſtification is aſcribed to faith?Rom. • . •

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bicauſe that in ſtead of bringing to God any thing that is of man, he bringeth him to Ieſus chriſt to receiue of him therby, that whiche hée can not fynde in himſelfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For what cauſe is this done?Rom. 3. •

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To the ende that man may be founde iuſt before God, not by his owne iuſtice: for he can not but by that of Ieſus Chriſte.

div.head: Of the ſatisfaction by faith.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: THy meaning is then yt this iuſtice of Ieſus Chriſt maketh a man iuſt,Rom. 3. c. d. 4. d. 1. Cor. 1. d. 2. Cor. 5. d. Rom. 7. a. 8 a. b. Epheſ. 2. a. b 1. Theſsa. 4. a. b. Tite. 2. c. d. before God, as though he were wholly innocent: forſomuche as GOD eſtéemeth him for ſuch an one, accepting the Iuſtice of his ſonne Ieſus Chryſte, for full ſatiſfaction.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is ſo, and it bringeth yet beſide that, an other very great commodity.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is that where as before hée coulde doe nothyng but euill, this fayth dothe ſanctifie him, diſpoſing
him to the obedience of the will of God,1. Peter. 1. a. Rom. 6. c. d. Matth. 1 c. d Eſa. 7. c. Luke. 1. c. 2. d. Matth. 3. d. Luke. 3. c. Iohn. 1. c. 3. d. Iohn. 17. d. Hebr. 10. b. Rom. 8. b. c Galath. 5. c. d. Rom. 8. b. e Galat. 5. c. d and to all good works, to the ende that he may ſerue to iuſtice & to holyneſſe, where as before he ſerued to iniuſtice and to ſinne.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How is it that faith doth ſanctifie man according to thy ſaying?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There be two things to conſider in this ſanctification.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the firſt?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that Ieſus Chriſte hauing taken our owne fleſh in the wombe of the Virgin, in the which he was conceiued by the working of the holy Ghoſt, hath alſo ſanctified it in his. Of which thing beſide the teſtimonie that we haue of the Angell in the holy Scriptures, the holy Ghoſt hath yet yelded more ample teſtimonie in the baptiſme of Ieſus Chriſt, when in fourme of a doue, he did deſcend vppon him, whiche is our head, in whome all his members were foorthwith ſanctified.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the other pointe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is that faith whiche embraceth and receyueth wholly Ieſus Chriſt with al his gifts and graces, is neuer in man without the ſpirite of him, nor the ſpirite of him, without his frutes, whiche are altogither contrary to the works of the fleſh, to witte, of the corrupted
man that is not regenerate by the ſpirite of God.

div.head: Of the true ſpring of good vvorks.

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: DEclare vnto me if thou vnderſtandeſt by this, that faith is the fountaine of all good works, and the good roote whiche maketh man a good trée, to beare good frute, wher as before he was an euil trée and bare euill frute?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It cannot bée otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I thinke then it is the cauſe why Sainct Paule, ſpeaking of the true Chriſtian faith, doth call it the liuing and working ſaith thorough charitie:Iames. 2. c. d. and why Saincte Iames ſaith that the faith that is withoute works is dead.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no doubte of it.

div.head: Of the accomplishing of the lavve in Ieſus Chriſt, and of the difference that is betvvene the iuſtification and ſanctification of a Chriſtian man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
SEing then, that man is ſo refourmed by the meane of faythe,
thou wilte then ſaye that he is otherwiſe diſpoſed to obey the lawe of God, than he was before, whē he was yet in his owne naturall.Iohn. 3. d. Iames. 1. c. 1. Peter. 1. d Rom. 7. c 2. Cor. 5. a. 1. Iohn. 1. d. Pſal. 143. a. Rom. 7. d. Phili. 3. b. c 1. Iohn. 2. a

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is eaſie to vnderſtande by that which we haue already ſaid.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: May we then in no wiſe obey the lawe of god, excepte that we be firſt regenerate by his ſpirite, and refourmed to his Image?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No in déede.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If we cā in no ſorte obey, we are then farre off from yelding perfecte obedience to the whole lawe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is true.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is the cauſe thereof?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is for that that our regeneration and reformation, is neuer fully perfecte in vs, ſo long as we are wrapped in this corruptable fleſh in this worlde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What other remedy is there then?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is to haue recourſe to the iuſtification which we haue alredy obteyned thorough the faith in Ieſus Chriſte, by the whiche we do alſo obtaine dayly remiſſion of all our ſinnes. For albeit that our ſanctification be not yet thoroughly perfecte, yet notwithſtanding that ſame letteth not, but that our iuſtification is alredy perfecte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doeſt thou meane that our iuſtification doth ſupplie that which wanteth of our ſanctification.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I can not tel whether thou takeſt my wordes, as though I meant that we might ſatiſfie towards God in parte, by our good works, the which we impute to ſatiſfactiō, and that Ieſus Chriſt ſhuld ſatiſfy only for the reſt for vs, by the ſame that may be on his ſide being alowed vnto vs by the iuſtificatiō. For if thou didſt ſo vnderſtand it, thou ſhuldeſt greatly deceiue thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wherein?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Chiefly in two points.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Shew me the firſt.Eſay. 43. b. Act. 4. b. 2. Timo. 1. c.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is in that thou ſhouldeſt ſpoile God at the leaſt of a great parte of the honor which is due vnto him, for the ſaluation which we haue of him, by Ieſus Chryſte, and the other parte we ſhall attribute to man.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In what ſorte?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In that that by this meane he ſhould be our ſauioure, but for the one halfe, and wée for the other.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Which is the other point?Eſay. 54. c. Luke. 17. c

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is that thou ſhouldeſt preſente to God, a ſatiſfaction ouermuche imperfecte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
I confeſſe, if I ſhould preſent vnto him but my works: but when I ſhal preſent vnto him my works for ſatiſfaction, and thē the ſatiſfaction whiche Chriſt hath made for me with them: What imperfection
then may more remaine?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If the ſatiſfaction of Ieſus Chriſt be ſufficiente, thou néedeſt to preſent none other to God: if it be not ſufficiente,Iob. 4. d. Pſalme. 130. thou canſt not ſatiſfie that whiche maye there wante by any thing that thou canſt do.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bycauſe that God can allowe nothing for ſatiſfaction which is not pure, ſounde and perfecte as he is.

div.head: Of the diſtinction that ought to be had betvvene the cauſe of our ſaluation, and the teſtimonie of the ſame.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: EXpounde vnto me ſomewhat more plainly thy meaning in this.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will ſay vnto thée for the firſte, that we muſt put difference in this matter betwene the cauſe of our ſaluation, and the teſtimonie of the ſame, and then afterwarde betwene the ſanctification by Ieſus Chriſte whiche is imputed to vs, and that whiche is ioyned to our perſon.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What thinkeſt thou to be ye cauſe of our ſaluation?Galla. 3. d. Epheſ. 3. d.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ieſus Chriſt dwelling in vs by faith.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What meaneſt thou by the teſtimonie that we haue of the ſame?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The ſanctification whereof we nowe ſpeake.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Howe doeſt thou vnderſtande
that it is the teſtimonie of our ſaluation and of the cauſe of the ſame, and not the cauſe it ſelfe?Rom. 8. b. c. Gala. 5. c. d. Matth. 7. c. Iohn. 8. c. f.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For bycauſe it teſtifieth that Ieſus Chriſt dwelleth in vs, as the effecte teſtifieth of his cauſe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What followeth thereof?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That the cauſe is there, ſeing that we ſée the effects, to wit, Ieſus Chriſt with all his gifts & graces.

div.head: Of the difference that muſt be put betvvene the ſanctification by Chriſt, vvhich is atributed vnto vs, and that vvhich is ioyned to our perſon, as a qualitie ſticking to the ſame.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ANd what inconueniente were it to holde our ſanctification, for the cauſe of our ſaluation?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For the better vnderſtāding of al this matter, it is méete that I expound vnto thée yet the differēce betwene the ſanctificatiō of Ieſus Chriſt which is allowed vs, whereof I haue euē now ſpoken, and that which is ioyned to our proper perſo, and then the frutes of the ſame.Luke. 1. d, Act. 4. c. Hebr. 7. d.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What difference doſt thou put therein?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
I do call ſanctification properly that, whiche we conſider in the very perſon of Ieſus Chryſte,
the which ſanctification is not properlye ours, as a qualitie cōiuncte to our perſon, but only by imputation.Gene. 15. a. Rom. 4. a. d. 1. Corin. 1 d.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What meaneſt thou by that imputation?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That it is allowed vnto vs, as his iuſtice is attributed and allowed vnto vs, by the iuſtificatiō which we obteyne in him by faith.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is that the cauſe why Sainct Paule ſaith, that God hath made Ieſus Chryſte vnto vs wiſdome, iuſtice, ſanctification, and redemption?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no doubte of it, but it muſt be conſidered, that beſide this kinde of ſanctification,Rom. 6. d. 1. Theſsa. 4. b 1. Peter. 1. c. Iohn. 17. c. Hebr. 10. b. that is ſo imputed and allowed vnto vs, there is yet an other, that is ioyned to our very perſon, not only by imputation, but as a qualitie ſticking in vs, whiche procéedeth from that firſt kind of ſanctificatiō, wherof we haue euen now ſpoken.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What vertue hath euery of them in vs?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The firſte doth fully ſanctifie vs before God, bycauſe it is full and perfecte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The other, is it not of the ſame nature and force?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No. For it ſanctifieth vs but in parte.Roma. 7. c. d. Galla. 5. c.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: For what cauſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Bycauſe that it is but begonne in vs and not perfecte, wherefore it cannot fully ſanctifie
vs excepte it be full and perfecte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And when ſhall it be ſo?1. Cor. 15. f. g.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When our regeneration and reformation to the Image of God ſhall be.1. Theſsa. 5. d.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſhall not then bée in this mortall life?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is true, but it ſhal be in the life to come,Col. 3. a. 1. Iohn. 5. a. in the whiche our life, whiche is now hiddē in Ieſus Chriſt, ſhal be ſhewed, and what we be ſhall appeare, when we ſhall be made like to the glorious body of Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: Of the cauſe of the difference that is in theſe tvvo kindes of ſanctification.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: WHat is the very cauſe of this difference that thou putteſt betwene theſe two kindes of ſanctification?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I call the firſt perfecte.Luke. 1. d Daniel. 9. f. For that that it is the very ſanctification not only of the whiche Ieſus Chriſte is ſanctified in hys fleſh and humane nature, but alſo by reaſon whereof he is called the holy one of holy ones. For ſo muche as by the communication of the ſame he doth ſanctifie all his elected,Ephe. 1. a. 5. f. to make them holy and without blame before God, who hathe choſen them therevnto.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
If it be the
ſame ſanctification wherewith Ieſus Chriſt is ſanctified, and doth ſanctifie others, it is very certaine that it cannot be but perfecte.Epheſ. 3. d. Col. 2. a. b. Iohn. 1. b. 4. b

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If it be perfecte in him, it is alſo perfecte in vs, in ſo much as dwelling in vs by faith, we haue him with all the holyneſſe that he bringeth with hym, the which we euer drawe out of him, as of his true fountaine, the which we haue is our ſelues whē we haue Ieſus chriſt.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If we haue in Ieſus Chriſte the fountaine of all holyneſſe, whereby we are continually and perpetually ſanctified: What other imperfecte ſanctification may then be in vs?Rom. 7. d. Tite. 3. b. 1. Peter. 1. a. Rom. 6. d.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That which we cō ſider in our owne proper fleſhe and nature, regenerate and renewed by the ſpirite of God, which is as it were watered with ye ſtreames of that fountaine of all ſanctification, to make vs bring foorth the frutes of true ſanctification and holyneſſe, in the ſtead of the frutes of ſinne, which it brought foorth in time before,Hebr. 5. b. as the earth, whiche being curſed and barren, is afterwarde made fertile, and beareth better frutes by the bleſſing of God.

div.head: Of the cauſe of the imperfection that is in the ſanctification ioyned to our perſon, and of the vvorks vvhich proceede therof.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: THou wilte then ſaye that this ſeconde kinde of ſanctification is not only adherente to the perſon of Ieſus Chriſte,Roma. 8. b. c. and that it is not only ours by imputation, as is the firſte: but that it is alſo adherente to our fleſh and nature, as a new qualitie which Ieſus Chriſt hath put into vs by his holy ſpirite, whiche maketh our fleſh holy in it ſelfe, to do afterwardes holy workes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is euen ſo.Galla. 5. c. d. Ephe. 5. b.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou wilte then ſay alſo, that the holy works whiche men do, being ſo ſanctified, be the frutes of the ſame ſanctification.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
It is euen ſo: but bycauſe there remayneth continually muche of oure naturall corruption in our fleſhe whyleſt we are in thys worlde, there can procéede from vs no worke ſo hollye, but that it is founde very foule,Iob. 4. c. Eſay. 64. c.
and farre off from that perfect holyneſſe whiche God requireth of vs in all our works.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What wilte thou conclude by that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That our workes be ſo farre off from worthyneſſe to be preſented for ſatiſfaction, and to obteine ſaluation by thē, be they neuer ſo holy, that if he ſhoulde iudge of them according to the rigoure of his iudgemente, he ſhoulde fynde nothing therein but matter of condemnation.Rom. 11. a. 2. Timo. 1. c Epheſ. 2. b. Tite. 3. b. Matth. 7. c. 2. Peter. 1. b

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thou maiſt not denie for all that, but the good & holy works are very agréeable vnto him?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If it were otherwiſe, they ought not to be done: but thou muſt note herein, that they be not acceptable vnto him, as cauſe of our ſaluation, but as teſtimonie of the ſame.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Howe vnderſtandeſt thou that they be teſtimonies of our ſaluation?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
In that that they teſtifie that Ieſus Chriſte is in vs, and that he there worketh by his holy ſpirite. Wherefore it foloweth that we be iuſtified and ſanctified by the iuſtice and ſanctification of Ieſus Chriſt,Rom. 8. b. Gala. 5. d. 1. Cori. 1. d Rom. 7. d. 1. Iohn. 1. d the which God beholdeth, and for the regarde thereof he doth beare with the imperfection that yet remayneth in vs, and doth pardon vs
that wherin we do yet dayly offend him.

div.head: Of the meanes that vve haue tovvard God, in recompence of the imperfections vvhich alwayes dvvell in vs.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: IT ſéemeth vnto me that thou wilte ſaye in effecte, by all this diſcourſe which thou haſt made, that what regeneration and ſanctification ſoeuer there be in our fleſhe and nature, we are not yet for all that ſo pure nor ſo perfecte, but that we muſt haue continuall recourſe to the iuſtice and ſanctification of Ieſus Chriſt, which is ours,Rom. 4. a. not as a qualitie of iuſtice and ſanctitie ſticking and ioined to our perſon, but only for that that it is allowed and attributed vnto vs, as though it were our owne proper.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: So it is,Iohn. 13. b and therefore Ieſus Chryſte hath ſaide to the ſame effecte, that he that was alredy waſhed, had yet néede to waſh his feete.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What meaneth he by that manner of ſpeach?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
